quest_title: On moving down the group,there is gradual increase in ____________
explanation_txt:
As we move down the group atomic size increases.

So distance between nucleus and valence electrons increases which results in decrease in force of attraction between them.

Thus becomes easier to lose the valence electrons thereby increasing metallic property.
question_plain_title: On moving down the group,there is gradual increase in ____________

So distance between nucleus and valence electrons increases which results in decrease in force of attraction between them.

Thus becomes easier to lose the valence electrons thereby increasing metallic property.

quest_title: Which of the following can act both as Bronsted acid and Bronsted base
explanation_txt:
Those substance accept the proton are called Bronsted base and which is donate the proton are called Bronsted acid.

\(\begin{array} { l } { H C O _ { 3 } ^ { - } + H ^ { + } = H _ { 2 } C O _ { 3 } \text { Bronsted base. } } \\ { H C O _ { 3 } ^ { - } = H ^ { + } + C O _ { 3 } ^ { - } \text { Bronsted acid. } } \end{array}\)

quest_title: 40ml of 0.1N HCl are mixed with 20ml of 0.1M \(\text{H\({}_{2}\)SO\({}_{4}\).}\) The strength of the resulting solution will be
explanation_txt:
20 ml of 0.1 M H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) = 20 ml of 0.2 N H\(_2\)SO\(_4\)

Strength of resulting solution \(=\cfrac{N_1V_1+N_2V_2}{V_1+V_2}=\cfrac{40 \times 0.1N + 20 \times 0.2N}{40+20}=\cfrac{8}{60}=0.133N\)

quest_title: IUPAC name of \(C H _ { 3 }- C H ( O H ) -C H _ { 2 } -C H _ { 2 } -C O O H\) is
explanation_txt:
Here we have 2 functional groups -OH and -COOH and -COOH has higher order of preference than -OH . So numbering can be done as

\( \overset{5}C H _ { 3 }- \overset{4}C H ( O H ) -\overset{3}C H _ { 2 } -\overset{2}C H _ { 2 } -\overset{1}C O O H\)

So its correct name is 4-hydroxy pentanoic acid

quest_title: Following sets of three forces act on a body. Whose resultant cannot be zero?
explanation_txt:
In the fourth option, maximum force is 40. Let's check the condition for minimum resultant. If the other two forces 10 and 20 acts opposite to the force 40, net force = 40 - 10 - 20 = 10. Therefore, the set of forces in fourth option cannot sum to zero.

But for all other sets of forces in other options, 0 lies in between maximum and minimum resultant.
question_plain_title: Following sets of three forces act on a body. Whose resultant cannot be zero?
explanation_plain_text:
In the fourth option, maximum force is 40. Let's check the condition for minimum resultant. If the other two forces 10 and 20 acts opposite to the force 40, net force = 40 - 10 - 20 = 10. Therefore, the set of forces in fourth option cannot sum to zero.

But for all other sets of forces in other options, 0 lies in between maximum and minimum resultant.

question_plain_title: What happens to the centripetal acceleration of a revolving body if you double the orbital speed and half the angular velocity ?
explanation_plain_text: i.e. remains constant.

quest_title: Thermoelectric thermometer is based on
explanation_txt:
Thermoelectric thermometer is based on Seeback Effect.

The Seebeck effect is a phenomenon in which a temperature difference between two dissimilar electrical conductors produces a voltage difference between the two substances. This voltage difference is used to measure the temperature of body.
question_plain_title: Thermoelectric thermometer is based on
explanation_plain_text:
Thermoelectric thermometer is based on Seeback Effect.

The Seebeck effect is a phenomenon in which a temperature difference between two dissimilar electrical conductors produces a voltage difference between the two substances. This voltage difference is used to measure the temperature of body.

quest_title: If temperature scale is changed from °C to °F, the numerical value of specific heat will
explanation_txt:
\(Q = m . c . \Delta \theta \Rightarrow c = \cfrac { Q } { m . \Delta \theta }\)

In temperature measurement scale \(\Delta \theta ^ { \circ } F > \Delta \theta ^ { \circ } C\) so \(( c ) _ { ^{\circ }F} < ( c ) _ { ^{\circ }C}\) .

quest_title: Two slab consist a two parallel layers of two different material of same thickness and having thermal conductivities K\({}_{1}\) and K\({}_{2}\). The equivalent thermal conductivity of slab is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\cfrac{l_{e q}}{\operatorname{Req}} &=\cfrac{l_{1}+l_{2}}{\left(R_{1}+R_{2}\right) A} \\ &=\cfrac{2 l}{\left(\cfrac{l}{k_{1} A}+\cfrac{l}{k_{2} A}\right)_{A}}=\cfrac{2 k_{1} k_{2}}{k_{1}+k_{2}} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A thin convex lens of focal length 10 \(\textit{cm}\) is placed in contact with a concave lens of same material and of same focal length. The focal length of combination will be
explanation_txt:
Resultant focal length \(\cfrac{1}{F}=\cfrac{1}{f_{1}}+\cfrac{1}{f_{2}}=\cfrac{1}{0.1}+\cfrac{1}{-0.1}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow F=\infty \)

quest_title: The maximum intensity of fringes in Young's experiment is I. If one of the slits is closed, then the intensity at that place becomes Io. Which of the following relation is true?
explanation_txt:
Suppose slit width’s are equal, so they produces waves of equal intensity say \(I'\). Resultant intensity at any point \(I _ { R } = 4 I' \cos ^ { 2 } \phi\) where \(\phi\) is the phase difference between the waves at the point of observation.

For maximum intensity \(\phi = 0 ^ { \circ } \Rightarrow I _ { \max } = 4 I ' = I\) …(i)

If one of slit is closed, Resultant intensity at the same point will be \(I^{'}\) only i.e. \(I ^ { \prime } = I _ { 0 }\) …(ii)

Comparing equation (i) and (ii) we get

\(I = 4 I _ {0}\)
question_plain_title: The maximum intensity of fringes in Young's experiment is I. If one of the slits is closed, then the intensity at that place becomes Io. Which of the following relation is true?
explanation_plain_text:

For maximum intensity …(i)

If one of slit is closed, Resultant intensity at the same point will be only i.e. …(ii)

Comparing equation (i) and (ii) we get
ans4_plain_text: There is no relation between and

quest_title: What will be the angular width of central maxima in Fraunhofer diffraction when light of wavelength \(6000 A\) is used and slit width is \(12 \times 10 ^ { - 5 } \mathrm { cm }\)?
explanation_txt: Angular width \(= \cfrac { 2 \lambda } { d } = \cfrac { 2 \times 6000 \times 10 ^ { - 10 } } { 12 \times 10 ^ { - 5 } \times 10 ^ { - 2 } } = 1\) rad.

quest_title: Specific charge of an ion is 4.4 \(\times\) 10\({}^{7}\) C/kg has a velocity of 3.5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{5}\) m/s and moves in a circular path in a uniform magnetic flux density 0.4 \(\text{T}\). The radius of circular path is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} e / m &=4.4 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{kg} \\ v=& 3.5 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ B=& 0.4 T \\ & B e v=\cfrac{m v^{2}}{r} \Rightarrow r=\cfrac{v}{B(e / m)} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: Specific charge of an ion is 4.4 10 C/kg has a velocity of 3.5 10 m/s and moves in a circular path in a uniform magnetic flux density 0.4 . The radius of circular path is

ans2_plain_text: 3 10 m
ans3_plain_text: 4 10 m
ans4_plain_text: 5 10 m

quest_title: If luminous efficiency of a lamp is 2 lumen/watt and its luminous intensity is 42 candela, then power of the lamp is
explanation_txt:
Luminous flux \((\phi)=\) Solid Angle \(\times\) Luminous intensity \(=4\pi \; L\)\(=4\times 3.14\times 42\; =\; 528\) \(\text{Lumen}\)

Power of lamp \(=\cfrac{{\rm Luminous}\; {\rm flux}}{{\rm Luminous}\, {\rm efficiency}} \)\(=\cfrac{528}{2} =264\; W\)

explanation_plain_text:
Luminous flux Solid Angle Luminous intensity

Power of lamp

quest_title: A pond is 5m deep and a flame is held 2m above the surface of water. A fish is at a depth 4m from surface of water then apparent height of flame form eyes of fish is
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)Apparent height = real height \(\times \)\(\mu\)

\(\quad\)\(\quad\) = \(2\times \)\( \cfrac{4}{3} \) = \( \cfrac{8}{3} \)

\(\quad\)Total apparent distance = 4 + \( \cfrac{8}{3} = \cfrac{20}{3} \)m

= =

quest_title: An air core solenoid has 1000 turns and is one \(\textit{metre}\) long. Its cross-sectional area is 10 \(\textit{cm}\)\({}^{2}\). Its self inductance is
explanation_txt: Self Inductance \(L=\cfrac{\mu _{0} N^{2} A}{l} =\cfrac{4\pi \times 10^{-7} \times (1000)^{2} \times 10\times 10^{-4} }{1} \) \(\textit{=}\)1.256\(\textit{ mH}\)
question_plain_title: An air core solenoid has 1000 turns and is one long. Its cross-sectional area is 10 . Its self inductance is
explanation_plain_text: Self Inductance 1.256

quest_title: A bar magnet of length 10 cm and having the pole strength equal to 10\({}^{-3}\) Wb is kept in a magnetic field having magnetic induction equal to 4\(\text{\(\pi\)}\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{-3}\) T. It makes an angle 30\(^\circ\) with the direction of magnetic induction. The value of the torque acting on the magnet is \(\text{\(\mu\)}\)\({}_{0}\) = 4\(\text{\(\pi\)}\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{-7}\) Wb A\({}^{-1}\) m.
explanation_txt:
Pole strength \((m)=10^{-3} \mathrm{Wb}=\cfrac{10^{-3}}{\mu_{0}} \mathrm{Am}\)
Magnetic moment \((M)=m \times 2 l=\cfrac{10^{-3}}{\mu_{0}} \times 0.1\)
\(\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,=m \times 2 l=\cfrac{10^{-4}}{\mu_{0}}\)
question_plain_title: A bar magnet of length 10 cm and having the pole strength equal to 10 Wb is kept in a magnetic field having magnetic induction equal to 4 10 T. It makes an angle 30 with the direction of magnetic induction. The value of the torque acting on the magnet is = 4 10 Wb A m.
explanation_plain_text:
Pole strength
Magnetic moment
ans1_plain_text: 2 10 Nm
ans2_plain_text: 2 10 Nm
ans4_plain_text: 0.5 10 Nm

quest_title:
The equilibrium constant of 
 \(\text{N\(_{2}\)}\) + \(\text{3H\(_{2}\)}\)   \(\leftrightharpoons\) \(\text{2NH\(_{3}\)}\) 
 is K, the equilibrium constant of 
 \(\text{\(\cfrac{1}{2}\)N\(_{2}\)}\) + \( \cfrac{3}{2} \) \(\text{H\(_{2}\)}\)   \(\leftrightharpoons\)  \(\text{NH\(_{3}\)}\) is
explanation_txt:
We have,

\(N_2 + 3H_2 \rightleftharpoons 2NH_3\)

So, 

\( K_1 = \cfrac{[NH_3]^2}{[N_2][H_2]^3} \cdots\cdots (i)\)

Also,

\(\cfrac{1}{2} N_2 + \cfrac{3}{2} H_2 \rightleftharpoons NH_3 \)

\(K_2 = \cfrac{[NH_3]}{[N_2]^{1/2}[H_2]^{3/2}} \\ K_2 ^ 2 = \cfrac{[NH_3]^2}{[N_2][H_2]^3} = K_1 \\ \Rightarrow K_2 = \sqrt{K_1}\)

explanation_txt:

quest_title: Addition of iron fillings to \(CuSO_4\) solution causes precipitation of \(Cu\) due to
explanation_txt:
Copper being electronegative than iron, is displaced from its salt, here sulphate.

\( Fe + CuSO_4 \to FeSO_4 + Cu \\ Fe + Cu^{2+} \to Fe^{2+} + Cu \)

quest_title: The products formed at cathode & anode by electrolysis of sq. \(\text{CuSO\(_{4}\)}\) using Cu electrodes are
explanation_txt:
At cathode:

\(Cu^{++} + 2e^- \longrightarrow Cu\)

Cu gets deposited

At anode:

\(SO_4^{--} + Cu^{++} \longrightarrow CuSO_4\)

The thickness of anode will decrease.

But, \(CuSO_4\) will dissociate into \(Cu^{++} \text{ and } SO_4^{--}\)
question_plain_title: The products formed at cathode & anode by electrolysis of sq. using Cu electrodes are
explanation_plain_text:
At cathode:

Cu gets deposited

At anode:

The thickness of anode will decrease.

But, will dissociate into
ans1_plain_text: &

quest_title: The domain of function \(f ( x ) = \sqrt { x - x ^ { 2 } } + \sqrt { 4 + x } + \sqrt { 4 - x }\) is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { f ( x ) = \sqrt { x - x ^ { 2 } } + \sqrt { 4 + x } + \sqrt { 4 - x } } \\ { \text { Clearly } f ( x ) \text { is defined, if } 4 + x \geq 0 \Rightarrow x \geq - 4 } \\ { 4 - x \geq 0 \Rightarrow x \leq 4 } \\ { x ( 1 - x ) \geq 0 \Rightarrow x \geq 0 \text { and } x \leq 1 } \\ { \therefore \text { Domain of } f = ( - \infty , 4 ] \cap [ - 4 , \infty ) \cap [ 0,1 ] = [ 0,1 ] } \end{array}\)
question_plain_title: The domain of function is

quest_title: In the system CN¯ + \(\text{H\(_{2}\)O}\)  \(\xrightarrow[]{}\) HCN + OH¯, the conjugate pairs are
explanation_txt:
\(\underset{Base}{CN^-} +\underset{Acid}{H_2O} \to \underset{conjugate\, acid}{HCN} + \underset{conjugate\, base}{OH^-}\)

Here \(CN^-\) accepted a proton from \(H_2O\) and \(HCN\) is formed. So \(CN^-\) is a base and its conjugate acid is \(HCN\)
question_plain_title: In the system CN¯ + HCN + OH¯, the conjugate pairs are
explanation_plain_text: Here accepted a proton from and is formed. So is a base and its conjugate acid is
ans1_plain_text: CN¯ / HCN and / HCN
ans2_plain_text: CN¯ / and HCN / OH¯
ans3_plain_text: CN¯/HCN and / OH¯

quest_title: 1gm marble when reacted with 1N HCl acid required 19ml for complete reaction leaving behind some sandy materials. The percentage purity of \(\text{CaCO\({}_{3}\)}\) in the marble is
explanation_txt:
Amount of CaCO\(_3\) = No. of gram equivalents of acid \(\times\) Equivalent Weight of CaCO\(_3\) = 0.019*1*50 = 0.95 gm

Hence, CaCO\(_3\) is 95% pure.
question_plain_title: 1gm marble when reacted with 1N HCl acid required 19ml for complete reaction leaving behind some sandy materials. The percentage purity of in the marble is
explanation_plain_text:
Amount of CaCO = No. of gram equivalents of acid Equivalent Weight of CaCO = 0.019*1*50 = 0.95 gm

Hence, CaCO is 95% pure.
